numbered_ace_sentences: 1. The graph shows a percentage of young adults.
2. Each young adult is between 18 years and 34 years old.
3. The percentage is the percentage of young adults who reach out to a parent at least once a day or a few times a week.
4. The graph breaks down communication methods.
5. One communication method is sending texts.
6. One communication method is a phone call or a video-chat.
7. One communication method is visiting in person.
8. Young women appear to reach out to their families at a higher rate than young men do.
9. This difference appears for each communication method.
10. Texting is the most common communication method.
11. Texting has the highest percentages for young women and for young men.
12. Visiting in person shows the lowest gap between genders.
13. However, visiting in person is less popular than the other communication methods.
14. I wonder how socialization of female children and male children impacts contact with parents.
15. I wonder how socialization impacts the way of contact with parents.
16. I wonder how socialization impacts the frequency of contact with parents.
17. I ask whether girls are more prone to keeping in touch with parents.
18. I ask whether girls spent more time with parents.
19. I ask whether girls feel that keeping in touch is expected.
20. Some participants have high rates of contact with parents.
21. I ask how many of these participants are eldest children.
22. I ask how many of these participants are only children.
23. This graph resonates with me.
24. My mom and I text nearly every day.
25. Video calls are harder to schedule than texts.
26. Phone calls are harder to schedule than texts.
27. In-person visits are the hardest to schedule.
28. My mom and I see each other a handful of times each year.
29. I think that schedule convenience influences the rates in the graph.
30. The headline could be: Texts and Calls: The New Bridge Between Today's Young Adults and Their Parents.
